user.biography: One of NASA's Great Observatories, helping us understand the structure & evolution of the Universe. For our Privacy Policy: http://www.si.edu/Privacy

node.text:
🔭🖼️ Are you up for a challenge? Participate in #NASA's Summer #AstrophotoChallenges! Use real telescope data to process your own images of this season's target, galaxy M87. 

👀 Watch the video to learn more and then get started by following the link at: https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/

#astronomy #space #astro #photo #project #enter

node.accessibility_caption: This image of Chandra Deep Field-South contains many dots of color scattered on a the mostly black background of space. The colors in this image represent different levels of X-ray energy detected by Chandra. The lowest-energy X-rays are red, the medium band is green, and the highest-energy X-rays observed by Chandra are blue. Roughly 70% of the colored dots in this image are supermassive black holes.

node.text:
🔴🟢🔵 Happy #DeepFieldWeek! The central region of this Chandra Deep Field-South image contains the highest concentration of supermassive black holes ever seen, equivalent to about 5,000 objects that would fit into the area on the sky covered by the full Moon and about a billion over the entire sky! Made with over 7 million seconds of observing time, this is the deepest X-ray image ever captured. 

🔍Take a deeper dive into the Deep Field: https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/

🖼️Want this #incredible #pic as #background #wallpaper for your phone or tablet? https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/wallpaper/

X-ray (Chandra): #NASA, CXC, Penn State/B.Luo et al.

#space #science #deep #field #astronomy #BlackHoles #learning

node.accessibility_caption: This image of Chandra Deep Field-South contains many dots of color scattered on a the mostly black background of space. The colors in this image represent different levels of X-ray energy detected by Chandra. The lowest-energy X-rays are red, the medium band is green, and the highest-energy X-rays observed by Chandra are blue. Roughly 70% of the colored dots in this image are supermassive black holes.
(Zoom in of image 1 showing more detail)
(Zoom in of image 1 showing more detail)
An image of face-on spiral galaxy NGC 6814. The galaxy has a bright nucleus and its sweeping arms are rippled with an intricate pattern of dark dust in this Hubble Space Telescope image.

node.text:
🌀Today Chandra is studying the sublime stellar swirl known as galaxy NGC 6814. Located about 71 million light years from Earth, the supermassive black hole near the center of this galaxy is roughly 10 million times more massive than our Sun.⚫

📱Get #space #wallpapers for your phone or tablet: https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/wallpaper/

Optical/IR: #NASA, ESA, #Hubble, & Judy Schmidt

#galaxy #astronomy #black #hole #swirl

node.accessibility_caption: This image of M81 is a composite of X-ray (purple), optical (cyan / gold), and infrared (red) data. The galaxy's spiral arms wind all the way down into its bright nucleus and the galaxy is thick with stars throughout.

Stars and dust lanes are revealed in this Hubble Space Telescope image of NGC 2841. A bright cusp of starlight marks the galaxy's center. Spiraling outward are dust lanes that are silhouetted against the population of whitish middle-aged stars. Much younger blue stars trace the spiral arms.

node.text:
NGC 2841 is located about 46 million light years from Earth in the constellation Ursa Major, the Great Bear 🐻. This majestic spiral galaxy is sometimes called the #Tiger's Eye Galaxy — its beautiful bands of gold resembling those of the gemstone with the same name. #TigerDay 🐯

🖼️ #Space #wallpaper for your phone or tablet (free): https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/wallpaper/

Credit: NASA, ESA and the Hubble Heritage Team

#astro #cosmos #galaxy

node.accessibility_caption: An image of NGC 1313 showing the galaxy's a barred spiral shape, with arms emanating outwards in a loose twist from the ends of the bar. Patches of young clusters of stars are present in the arms and to a lesser extent between the arms of the galaxy.

node.text:
✨Right now Chandra is studying a #supernova in the constellation Reticulum. Nearby in the sky is NGC 1313, a barred spiral #galaxy about half the diameter of our Milky Way. This galaxy's rather messy appearance, the result of patches of intense star formation, has earned it the nickname "Topsy-Turvy Galaxy."

📱Want #beautiful #space #wallpaper for your phone or tablet? https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/wallpaper/

Credit: ESO/VLT

#astronomy #science #cosmos #universe

node.accessibility_caption: An image of galaxy M82 in X-ray and optical light; X-rays from NuSTAR (purple) and Chandra (blue) that have been combined with optical data from the NOAO 2.1 meter telescope (gold).

node.text:
🌟When matter is pulled toward a dense, compact object, like a pulsar, neutron star, or black hole, it's heated and produces X-rays. Today Chandra is studying #pulsar M82 X-2, an ultraluminous X-ray source (ULX) that at its brightest is more than 10 times as bright as any other known pulsars of its type. 

Learn more about M82 X-2: https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/

X-ray (Chandra & NuSTAR): #NASA, CXC, Univ. of Toulouse/M.Bachetti et al.
Optical (NOAO 2.1 meter telescope): #NOAO, AURA, #NSF

📱Want #space #wallpaper for your phone or tablet? https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/wallpaper/

#stars #astronomy #hot #bright #ULX

node.accessibility_caption: An image of galaxy M82 in X-ray and optical light; X-rays from NuSTAR (purple) and Chandra (blue) that have been combined with optical data from the NOAO 2.1 meter telescope (gold).
Zoom-in: Closer field of view than image #1 showing the core of galaxy M82
Zoom-in: Even closer field of view than image #2 with M82 X-2 and M82 X-1 sources labeled

A cluster of stars almost completely surrounded by a colorful and detail-filled nebula. In this composite image the Chandra data is shown in purple, optical data from Hubble is shown in red, green and blue and infrared data from Spitzer is shown in red.

node.text:
🛰️To expand our understanding of the Universe and all of its wonders, scientists collect & analyze light emitted by phenomena across the electromagnetic spectrum. This image of NGC 602 combines light observed by NASA's Great Observatories — Chandra (X-ray), Hubble (optical), & Spitzer (infrared). Happy #SpaceExplorationDay!✨

🖼️Want this #beautiful #pic as #background #wallpaper for your phone or tablet? https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/wallpaper/

🔍Want to know more about the #science behind the #image? https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/

X-ray (Chandra X-ray Observatory): NASA, CXC, Univ.Potsdam/L.Oskinova et al;
Optical (#Hubble Space Telescope): NASA, STScI;
Infrared (Spitzer Space Telescope): #NASA, JPL-Caltech

#space #exploration is #amazing

node.accessibility_caption: This composite image of NGC 6338 contains X-ray data from Chandra (displayed in red) that shows hot gas as well as cooler gas detected with Chandra and XMM-Newton (shown in blue) that also emits X-rays. The Chandra data have been combined with optical data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey, showing the galaxies and stars in white.

node.text:
NGC 6338 is a system where two groups of #galaxies roughly 100 trillion times the mass of our Sun are plowing into each other at ~6 million kilometers per hour. One of the most violent collisions of this type ever witnessed, it's producing #hot temperatures near 20 million degrees Celsius.🌡️

📱Want this #pic as #wallpaper for your phone or tablet? https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/wallpaper/

🔍Want to know more about the #space #science behind the #image? https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/

X-ray (Chandra): #NASA, CXC, SAO, E. O'Sullivan
X-ray (XMM-Newton): #ESA, XMM, E. O'Sullivan
Optical: SDSS

node.text:
Today Chandra is observing Jupiter's auroras while NASA's Juno spacecraft explores the planet's magnetosphere. Jupiter's magnetic field funnels some of the charged particles in the magnetosphere toward the poles, where they interact with the atmosphere to produce brilliant auroras — northern & southern lights. 

Jupiter's magnetosphere is the largest structure in the solar system — about 5.3 million kilometers (3.3 million miles) wide on average and roughly 150 times wider than the planet itself.

🖼️Free #space #wallpaper: https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/wallpaper/

Video Credit: #NASA, GSFC, #Hubble, STScI

#planet #Jupiter #aurora #science

node.accessibility_caption:
The primary image of this release features a small galaxy cluster plowing through a larger one, leaving behind a wake of hot gas. 

The large galaxy cluster resembles a round cloud of neon blue squiggles, more dense on our left than on our right. Just below the center of this cloud is a light blue shape packed with blurry squiggles. It resembles a mushroom cap on its side, with a thin horizontal stem shaped like an umbrella handle sticking out the bottom, pointing to our left. The mushroom cap is hot gas in the smaller galaxy cluster. The umbrella handle is the wake of hot gas. Although, it's important to remember that small is a relative term. Galaxy clusters are the largest structures in the Universe held together by gravity, containing hundreds or even thousands of individual galaxies.

A red line that resembles a vapor trail left by an airplane cuts through the cloud. It extends from the bottom of the mushroom cap to the upper left of the large blue cloud-like galaxy cluster. This is a jet from a supermassive black hole on the left side of the small mushroom-cap galaxy cluster.

There are two other red lines inside the blue cloud. Both are shorter and more translucent than the jet, but they all have one end near the bottom of the side-facing mushroom cap. The long jet exits the blue cloud at 11 on a clock face. The next longest points toward 10, and the faintest follows the path of the light blue mushroom stem. The origin of these two red tendrils is less clear, but they are likely related to gas motions in the colliding clusters.

node.text:
💥When the titans of #space — galaxy clusters — collide, extraordinary things can happen. A #new study using NASA's Chandra examines the repercussions after clusters clashed in Abell 1775, a system where a smaller #galaxy cluster has plowed into a larger one. (More in the comments...)

📱 Want this #amazing #pic as #wallpaper for your phone or tablet? https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/wallpaper/

🤔 Want to know more about the #science behind the #image? https://chandra.harvard.edu/

X-ray (Chandra): #NASA, CXC, Leiden Univ./A. Botteon et al.; 
Radio: LOFAR/ASTRON; 
Optical/IR:PanSTARRS

#powerful #astrophysics #universe

node.accessibility_caption:
The primary image of this release features a small galaxy cluster plowing through a larger one, leaving behind a wake of hot gas. 

The large galaxy cluster resembles a round cloud of neon blue squiggles, more dense on our left than on our right. Just below the center of this cloud is a light blue shape packed with blurry squiggles. It resembles a mushroom cap on its side, with a thin horizontal stem shaped like an umbrella handle sticking out the bottom, pointing to our left. The mushroom cap is hot gas in the smaller galaxy cluster. The umbrella handle is the wake of hot gas. Although, it's important to remember that small is a relative term. Galaxy clusters are the largest structures in the Universe held together by gravity, containing hundreds or even thousands of individual galaxies.

A red line that resembles a vapor trail left by an airplane cuts through the cloud. It extends from the bottom of the mushroom cap to the upper left of the large blue cloud-like galaxy cluster. This is a jet from a supermassive black hole on the left side of the small mushroom-cap galaxy cluster.

There are two other red lines inside the blue cloud. Both are shorter and more translucent than the jet, but they all have one end near the bottom of the side-facing mushroom cap. The long jet exits the blue cloud at 11 on a clock face. The next longest points toward 10, and the faintest follows the path of the light blue mushroom stem. The origin of these two red tendrils is less clear, but they are likely related to gas motions in the colliding clusters.
Photo by NASA Chandra X-ray Observatory on July 15, 2021. May be an image of sky and text.
A bright central source surrounded by a cloud of gas (blue) with two distinct cavities in the gas at the top and bottom. Jets extend from the central source into and through the cavities (pink).

node.text:
This galaxy cluster is home to one of the most #powerful #BlackHole eruptions ever observed. Jets from a supermassive black hole weighing nearly a billion times the mass of our Sun have displaced more than 1 trillion solar masses worth of gas. The power required to displace the gas exceeds the power output of our Sun by nearly ten trillion times in the past 100 million years.☀️

This image of galaxy cluster MS 0735.6+7421 is about 2 million light years across.

📱Want this #stunning #pic as #background #wallpaper for your phone or tablet? https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/wallpaper/

🔍Want to know more about the #space #science behind the #image? https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/

X-ray (Chandra): NASA, CXC, Univ. of Waterloo/A.Vantyghem et al; 
Optical (#Hubble): NASA/STScI; 
Radio (Very Large Array): NRAO

#wow #amazing #hot #astrophysics

node.accessibility_caption: A barred spiral galaxy oriented almost face-on with other galaxies present in the background

node.text:
⚫Today Chandra is studying the supermassive #BlackHole in the core of #galaxy Markarian 817. This beast of a black hole is roughly 40 million times more massive than our Sun and its powerful forces are propelling matter through #space at over 14 million kilometers per hour.

🖼️Want #wallpaper for your phone or tablet? https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/wallpaper/

Optical/Infrared: #NASA, ESA, #Hubble

#astronomy #galaxies #astrophysics #powerful #fast
